articles.headline: What Do You Do When A.I. Takes Your Voice?
articles.snippet: Two voice actors say an A.I. company created clones of their voices without their permission. Now they’re suing. The company denies it did anything wrong.
articles.abstract: Two voice actors say an A.I. company created clones of their voices without their permission. Now they’re suing. The company denies it did anything wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, as they drove to a doctor’s appointment near their home in Manhattan, Paul Skye Lehrman and Linnea Sage listened to a podcast about the rise of artificial intelligence and the threat it posed to the livelihoods of writers, actors and other entertainment professionals.

articles.headline: As Russia Advances, NATO Considers Sending Trainers Into Ukraine
articles.snippet: The move could draw the United States and Europe more directly into the war. The Biden administration continues to say there will be no American troops on the ground.
articles.abstract: The move could draw the United States and Europe more directly into the war. The Biden administration continues to say there will be no American troops on the ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: NATO allies are inching closer to sending troops into Ukraine to train Ukrainian forces, a move that would be another blurring of a previous red line and could draw the United States and Europe more directly into the war.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and Lara Jakes

articles.headline: Texas Governor Pardons Man in Fatal Shooting of Protester in 2020
articles.snippet: The man, Daniel S. Perry, was convicted of killing a protester during a Black Lives Matter demonstration in Austin.
articles.abstract: The man, Daniel S. Perry, was convicted of killing a protester during a Black Lives Matter demonstration in Austin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Thursday pardoned a man who was convicted of fatally shooting a protester during a Black Lives Matter demonstration in the summer of 2020, fulfilling a promise he made last year amid pressure from conservatives.

articles.headline: Slovakia’s Politics Were Toxic Long Before Its Prime Minister Was Shot
articles.snippet: Years of vitriolic rhetoric, worsened by the Covid-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine, left Slovakia with bitter political division.
articles.abstract: Years of vitriolic rhetoric, worsened by the Covid-19 pandemic and the war in Ukraine, left Slovakia with bitter political division.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the government that charged him, he was a “lone wolf,” an off-kilter individual representing nobody but himself when he pumped at least four bullets into Prime Minister Robert Fico of Slovakia.
articles.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Cassandra Vinograd

articles.headline: At Justice Alito’s House, a ‘Stop the Steal’ Symbol on Display
articles.snippet: An upside-down flag, adopted by Trump supporters contesting the Biden victory, flew over the justice’s front lawn as the Supreme Court was considering an election case.
articles.abstract: An upside-down flag, adopted by Trump supporters contesting the Biden victory, flew over the justice’s front lawn as the Supreme Court was considering an election case.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the 2020 presidential election, as some Trump supporters falsely claimed that President Biden had stolen the office, many of them displayed a startling symbol outside their homes, on their cars and in online posts: an upside-down American flag.

articles.headline: Taiwan, on China’s Doorstep, Is Dealing With TikTok Its Own Way
articles.snippet: The island democracy was early to ban TikTok on government phones, and the ruling party refuses to use it. But a U.S.-style ban is not under consideration.
articles.abstract: The island democracy was early to ban TikTok on government phones, and the ruling party refuses to use it. But a U.S.-style ban is not under consideration.
articles.lead_paragraph: As it is in the United States, TikTok is popular in Taiwan, used by a quarter of the island’s 23 million residents.
articles.byline: By Meaghan Tobin and Amy Chang Chien

articles.headline: China Says It Will Start Buying Apartments as Housing Slump Worsens
articles.snippet: Signaling growing alarm, policymakers ramped up efforts to stem a continued decline in real estate values.
articles.abstract: Signaling growing alarm, policymakers ramped up efforts to stem a continued decline in real estate values.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a housing crisis that shows no end, the Chinese government is stepping in as a buyer of last resort.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Siyi Zhao

articles.headline: How Kite Surfing in Remote Colombia Changed a Boy. And a Village.
articles.snippet: The sport came to Beto Gomez’s small Indigenous town nearly two decades ago. Despite some resistance back home, he is now the world’s only professional kite surfer with Wayuu roots.
articles.abstract: The sport came to Beto Gomez’s small Indigenous town nearly two decades ago. Despite some resistance back home, he is now the world’s only professional kite surfer with Wayuu roots.
articles.lead_paragraph: They came from all over the world to this remote stretch of Colombia’s Caribbean coast. Two hailed from India. Two traveled from Switzerland. One from the Netherlands. Another from Seattle. They all wanted to be taught by Beto Gomez, a professional kite surfer, in the spot where he first learned the sport.
articles.byline: By James Wagner and Federico Rios

articles.headline: Some Conservative Christians Are Stepping Away From the Gender Wars
articles.snippet: Far from the shouting, Christian therapists, writers, parents and their trans children are trying to create a space within conservative circles to acknowledge differences in how people experience gender.
articles.abstract: Far from the shouting, Christian therapists, writers, parents and their trans children are trying to create a space within conservative circles to acknowledge differences in how people experience gender.
articles.lead_paragraph: Andrew and Debbie James are evangelical Christians. Born in England, the couple moved to Denver years ago and raised their children there. Mrs. James had a profound religious conversion experience early in parenthood, and their large nondenominational church quickly became the focal point of their lives. They used to say that if the doors were open, they were there.
